111893 S2468-8231(21)00510-1 10.1016/j.mcat.2021.111893 Scheme 1 Reaction pathway of aldol condensation between furfural and acetone. Scheme 1 Fig. 1 XRD patterns of La2O2CO3-Al2O3 catalysts. (a) pH 10–800 °C-2 h, (b) pH 10–700 °C-2 h, (c) pH 10–600 °C-2 h, (d) pH 10–700 °C-6 h (e) pH 10–700 °C-4 h, (f) pH 9–700 °C-2 h, and (g) pH 8–700 °C-2 h, (h) La2O2CO3 (PDF#37–0804) and (i) La2O3 (PDF#54–0213). Fig 1 Fig. 2 Effect of reaction temperature to selectivity of FAc and F2Ac over La2O2CO3-Al2O3 catalyst. Reaction conditions: Pressure 10 bar, N2 atmosphere, reaction time 4 h, catalyst 0.2 g, water 20 mL, molar ratio of furfural/acetone 1/1, furfural 1 g. Fig 2 Fig. 3 Effect of furfural/acetone molar ratio to selectivity of FAc and F2Ac over La2O2CO3-Al2O3 catalyst. Reaction conditions: Pressure 10 bar, N2 atmosphere, reaction temperature: 80 °C, reaction time 4 h, catalyst 0.2 g, water 20 mL, furfural 1 g. Fig 3 Fig. 4 Effect of reaction time to selectivity of FAc and F2Ac over La2O2CO3-Al2O3 catalyst. Reaction conditions: Pressure 10 bar, N2 atmosphere, reaction temperature 80 °C, catalyst 0.2 g, water 20 mL, molar ratio of furfural/acetone 1/1, furfural 1 g. Fig 4 Fig. 5 Recycle experiments for La2O2CO3-Al2O3 catalyst for furfural conversion. Jet fuel precursors (4-(2-furyl)-3-buten-2-one (FAc) and 1,5-di-2-furanyl-1,4-pentadien-3-one (F2Ac)) can be produced from aldol condensation between furfural and acetone over basic catalysts. However, there is still a need to develop efficient alkaline catalysts and understand the role of alkaline sites. In this work, La2O2CO3-Al2O3 catalyst was successfully prepared by coprecipitation and the effect of preparation conditions on the properties and catalytic performance was investigated. Experiments showed that La2O2CO3 and La2O3 were formed after calcination, and the activity was greatly improved by the introduction of La2O2CO3. At higher coprecipitation pH, rod-shaped La2O2CO3 was formed, which exhibits higher exposure of basic La3+-O2− sites and shows good performance in aldol condensation reactions. The catalytic performance of La2O2CO3-Al2O3 in aldol condensation of furfural with acetone was also evaluated and compared with that of Al2O3, La2O3, La2O3-Al2O3, La(OH)₃/Al2O3 and La2O2CO3/Al2O3. A total conversion of furfural can be realized with F2Ac yield of 67.8% at a furfural/acetone ratio of 1/1 and 90 °C, with a FAc yield of 25.8% at the same time. The deactivation mechanism of the La2O2CO3-Al2O3 catalyst was also studied. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Biomass Furfural Aldol condensation La2O2CO3-Al2O3 1 Introduction Since the industrial revolution, the demand for modernization of society and economy has increased rapidly with the major consumption of oil, gas and coal [1,2]. Lignocellulose is the largest renewable biomass resource on the earth, and its development and utilization are considered to be one of the most effective ways to alleviate energy problems [3]. For the conversion process of lignocellulose, it has the advantages of mild reaction conditions and environmental friendliness and can obtain high-grade fuels and value-added chemicals [4]. Lignocellulose is composed of cellulose (40–50%), hemicellulose (25–30%) and lignin (15–20%) and other extractable components [5]. Generally, hemicellulose and cellulose can be hydrolyzed into five-carbon sugar (such as arabinose and xylose) and six-carbon sugar (such as glucose and fructose) [6]. These sugar monomers are dehydrated to produce furfural and 5-hydroxymethylfurfural, two important furan platform chemicals [7]. There are two main methods to produce hydrocarbons from the platform chemicals [8]. The direct hydrodeoxygenation of furfural or 5-hydroxymethylfurfural to produce C5-C6 alkanes is very poor [9]. C8-C15 alkanes can also be obtained by hydrodeoxygenation of the aldol condensation adduct of furfural/5-hydroxymethylfurfural and acetone [10]. Through these ways, biomass raw materials can be converted into high value-added aviation kerosene [11]. The reaction of aldol condensation is considered to be a key step in the production of alkanes from lignocellulose in the jet fuel range, as low carbon molecules such as furfural can be converted to high carbon chain precursors [12]. The process was proposed by Barrett et al. for obtaining high quality C8-C13 liquid fuel precursors from furfural [13]. The reaction between furfural and acetone initially produces 4-(2-furyl)−3-buten-2-one (FAc), which can react with another furfural molecule and form 1,5-di-2-furanyl-1,4-pentadien-3-one (F2Ac). Several homogeneous base catalysts, such as Ca(OH)2 and NaOH, were used to catalyze this aldol condensation reaction [14,15]. Significantly, the F2Ac yield can reach to 98.2% over NaOH [16]. On the other hand, the development of solid basic catalyst is also needed due to the recyclability and corrosion problems. For example, O'Neill et al. reported that natural dolomitic rocks can be used for aldol condensation reaction, and the yield of aldol condensation products of furfural and acetone is about 72% after 1 h at 150 °C [17]. In addition, basic mixed metal oxides including Mg-Al [18], Mg-Zr [19], Ca-Zr [20], and anion-exchange resins, were also applied to aldol condensation reactions [21]. Mg-Al mixed oxides derived from Mg-Al hydrotalcite show good furfural conversion, and FAc is the main product [18]. By using Pluronic 123 during synthesis of Mg/Al hydrotalcite precursor, the derived Mg/Al oxides showed bigger pore sizes and more surface-active sites, showed higher yield to F2Ac of 44.5% [22]. Huber et al. reported that hydroxymethylfurfural and furfural can undergo aldol condensation with acetone by Mg-Zr mixed oxides in a methanol-water biphasic system and the total yield of FAc and F2Ac is about 54% after 120 °C for 24 h [12]. Compared with the MgO-ZrO2, nitrogen-substituted NaY (Nit-NaY) catalyst obtained by nitrided in a flow ammonia showed a higher monomer product selectivity at similar furfural conversion. Nevertheless, the selectivity to aldol product was only 57.6% over Nit-NaY when furfural was totally consumed [23]. Fang et al. studied the aldol condensation of furfural (C5) with acetone (C3) with lower doses of water and acetone on Ca/ZSM-5. A C13 yield of 60.2% was obtained over Ca-ZSM-5–700 catalyst at 80 °C for 2 h [24]. The aldol condensation of furfural and acetone on MgF1.5(OH)0.5 catalyst was investigated, and the yield of F2Ac is about 60% (furfural/acetone ratio equal to 0.5) after 6 h of reaction at 50 °C at atmospheric pressure [25]. This work showed a good correlation between the catalytic activity and the basicity, highlighting the key role of basic sites. Sn-Beta catalyst was also investigated, showing a selectivity to FAc of 40% and F2Ac of 22%. On the contrary, only FAc was produced over Sn-MF [26]. K-promoted Sn-MFI can increase the total selectivity to aldol products to 93.6%, and the F2Ac selectivity was 24.6% at 160 °C for 1 h [27]. Desai and Yadav reported that a high selectivity of FAc (98%) can be achieved over La1Mg3MO catalyst with moderate to strong basicity. Based on the reported works, compared with FAc production, it can be found the highly selective synthesis of dimer (i.e., F2Ac) under mild conditions is still a challenge for solid basic catalyst [28]. La2O2CO3 is a kind of basic catalysts, which finds great applications in dehydrogenation, oxidation and condensation reactions. For example, 1-octanol can be dissociatively activated through the interaction of its OH bond with the surface La3+-O2− pairs, forming alkoxide species (La-O-CH2-R) [29]. Thus, the Cu/La2O2CO3 catalyst can efficiently catalyze transfer dehydrogenation of primary aliphatic alcohols to aldehydes. Besides, La2O2CO3 exhibited significant structure sensitivity to some reactions, like oxidative coupling of methane, in which La2O2CO3 with different morphologies exhibited different exposed facets and performance [30]. Moreover, the La2O2CO3 nanorods showed good performance in condensation reaction of benzaldehyde with acetophenone, and the reaction rate is directly related to the number of alkaline sites (La3+-O2− pairs) on the nanorods [31]. The La2O2CO3 promoted ZnO-Al2O3 catalysts for the furfural-acetone aldol condensation reaction was previously reported, and it was concluded that moderately alkaline site on La2O2CO3 is particularly active in the aldol condensation reaction [32]. However, studies about the role of lanthanum oxides are scarcely reported on aldol condensation of furfural and acetone. Our work started from synthesis of La2O2CO3-Al2O3 samples by co-precipitation method and investigated the preparation conditions (coprecipitation pH, calcination temperature, and calcination time) on the structure and catalytic performance of La2O2CO3-Al2O3. Then, orthogonal experiments were designed to optimize furfural conversion and illustrate the effect of reaction conditions on La2O2CO3-Al2O3 catalyst. The catalyst stability was also investigated. It was found that La2O2CO3 is the effective component in aldol condensation reaction. By controlled the synthesis of La2O2CO3 was increased the medium-strength basic amounts, which showed improved activity in furfural conversion and increased the yield of F2Ac. The developed catalytic system showed great potential applications in liquid fuel production and base-catalyzed reaction processes. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Chemicals and materials Sodium carbonate anhydrous (≥ 99.5%), sodium hydroxide (≥ 97%), aluminum nitrate nonahydrate (≥ 99%) were purchased from Aladdin Industrial Inc. (Shanghai). Furfural (≥ 99%), ethyl acetate (≥ 99.5%), aluminum oxide (≥ 99%), lanthanum(Ⅲ) oxide (≥ 99.99%), and lanthanum (Ⅲ) nitrate hydrate were bought from Shanghai chemical reagent Co., Ltd. (Shanghai). Furfural was stored in the fridge at 4 °C. Acetone (≥ 99.5%) was from Shanghai Lingfeng chemical regent Co., Ltd. Standard 4-(2-Furyl)−3-buten-2-one (FAc) was purchased from TCI development Co., Ltd. (Shanghai). Standard furfural was bought from Aladdin Industrial Inc. (Shanghai). 1,5-di-2-furanyl-1,4-pentadien-3-one (F2Ac) was purchased from Macklin Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. (Shanghai). Deionized water comes from a water purification system (electrical conductivity was 18.2 MΩ•cm, Milli-Q Academic, Merck Millipore, Darmstadt Germany). 2.2 Catalyst preparation Using La(NO3)3•6H2O and Al(NO3)3•9H2O as metal precursors, a series of La2O2CO3-Al2O3 catalysts were prepared by a conventional co-precipitation method. Na2CO3 and NaOH were used as precipitation agents. The detailed procedures for the preparation of La2O2CO3-Al2O3 catalysts were as follows. The metal salt solution with a molar concentration of 1 mol/L was prepared by mixing La(NO3)3•6H2O and Al(NO3)3•9H2O. A mixed solution of NaOH and Na2CO3 with a molar ratio of 1 was prepared as a precipitant. The metal salted solution and precipitant were simultaneously dropped into 200 mL of distilled water at 60 °C under intense agitation. During the precipitation process, the pH value of the solution is controlled by adjusting the amount of the precipitation agent. The resulting solution was vigorously stirred at 60 °C for 1 h and kept standing for 1.5 h. The resulting mixture is filtrated and washed with deionized water several times until the washing liquid is neutral. Subsequently, the sediment was dried at 105 °C for 6 h (WFO-710, EYELA, Tokyo Rikakikai Co., Ltd.), ground and sieved (< 80 mesh or 187.5 μm). The sediment was calcined at 700 °C for 2 h in a muffle furnace (KSL-1100X, Hefei Kejing Material Technology Co. Ltd). According to previous reports, the possible formation pathway to La2O2CO3 as follows [33]. (1) 2 La ( OH ) 3 + 2 C O 2 → L a 2 O ( C O 3 ) 2 + 3 H 2 O (2) L a 2 O ( C O 3 ) 2 → L a 2 O 2 C O 3 + C O 2 For comparison, some reference catalysts were prepared. La2O2CO3/Al2O3 catalyst was prepared by using the above method except that Al2O3 was used as starting materials instead of Al(NO3)3•9H2O. The metal salted solution and precipitant were added into 200 mL of distilled water containing Al2O3 powder. The derived material was dried at 105 °C and calcined at 700 °C. The La(OH)3/Al2O3 catalyst was prepared based on the above method and using Al2O3 as support. The obtained material was dried at 105 °C and used without calcination. The La2O3-Al2O3 catalyst was prepared by mixing La2O3 and Al2O3 in distilled water, and then stirring and drying at 70 °C. 2.3 Catalyst characterization X-Ray diffraction (XRD) with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.154 nm) in the range of 2θ from 5° to 90° to obtain XRD patterns. Physisorption data was obtained using Bruner-Emmett-Teller (BET) and Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) methods (Nova 4200 E, Quantachrome Instruments, Boynton Beach, FL). Laser diffraction particle size analyzer (Microtrac SDC, Microtrac, PA) was used to measure the diameter of particles. Fourier transform-infrared (FT-IR) spectra were obtained in a spectrophotometer (Nicolet IS10, Thermo Fisher Scientific Inc., Waltham, WA). Temperature programmed desorption of CO2 (CO2-TPD; Chembet PULSAR TPR/TPD, Quantachrome, Boynton Beach, FL) was used to measure the surface basicity. The sample (50 mg) was placed in a U-shaped quartz tube and purged with helium (100 mL/min) for 10 min and heated to 500 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C/min, and kept for another 150 min. Subsequently, the catalyst was cooled to 100 °C and purged with CO2 for 60 min, and purged with He for 90 min to remove the physisorbed CO2. At last, the sample was heated to 600 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min for the subsequent adsorption. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA; PerKinElmer, America) was analyzed in an air atmosphere at a heating rate of 10 °C /min from room temperature to 800 °C. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) spectra were recorded on a ESCALAB 250Xi spectrometer equipped with a monochromatic Al Kα (1486.8 eV) source (PHI5000 VersaProbe, ULVAC-PHI, Chichibu, Saitama, Japan). The charging effect of the catalysts was corrected by referring to the C 1 s peak of adventitious carbon (284.8 eV). Transmission electron microscopy (TEM, JEOL JEM-2100, JEOL Ltd.; Tokyo) was used to analyze the morphology of the catalyst. 2.4 Catalytic reaction and analysis method The reactions were carried out in a 50 mL agitator intermittent autoclave reactor equipped with a PID temperature controller and a back pressure regulator (NSC100-P5-T3-SS1-SV, Anhui Kemi Machinery Technology Co., Ltd., Hefei, China). Aqueous solution of furfural and acetone (20 mL), and catalyst (60–80 meshes) were added into the reactor. After sealed, the reator was purged five times with 50 bars of nitrogen. The reactions were performed at 60–90 °C under initial N2 pressure of 10 bars and magnetic stirring (800 rpm). Due to the poor solubility of F2Ac, products were extracted with ethyl acetate (1/1 by volume), and analyzed using gas chromatography (GC; (GC-2010 plus, Shimadzu, Kyoto), flame ionization detector (FID) and capillary column WondaCap 5 (30 m × Ф0.25 mm × 0.25 μm). Detector temperature, injector temperature and column temperature were set to 280oC, 260oC and 220 °C. The split flow ratio was 40/1 and the carrier gas was nitrogen with a flow rate 1 mL/min. The oven temperature program was initially set at 60 °C for 2 min and then increased to 230 °C in 17 min and maintained for 15 min. Calibration factors of each furanic adduct were determined by external reference method, in which the mixed standard of furfural, FAc and F2Ac were put into a 2 mL sample bottle and dilutated by ethyl acetate. The calibration factors and peak areas are shown in Fig. S1. The liquid samples were qualitatively analyzed by GC-MS (Agilent 7890–5977B, Santa Clara, CA) equipped with an HP-5 MS capillary column (30 m × 0.25 mm × 0.25 mm). Helium (99.999%) was used as carrier gas for split injection at a split ratio of 50. The oven temperature was held at 40 °C for 3 min, heated to 100 °C at 30 °C/min and then heated to 300 °C at 40 °C/min, held at 300 °C for 5 min. The catalytic performance was evaluated by furfural conversion, FAc and F2Ac selectivity. The equations were defined as [34]: (3) furfural conversion = moles of furfural reacted moles of furfural started × 100 % (4) FAc selectivity = moles of C 8 moles of furfural reacted × 100 % (5) F 2 Ac selectivit y = moles of C 13 moles of furfural reacted × 100 % (6) FAc yield = moles of C 8 moles of furfural started × 100 % (7) F 2 Ac yield = 2 × moles of C 13 moles of furfural started × 100 % (8) C balance = 8 × moles of C 8 + 13 × moles of C 13 + 5 × moles of C 5 + 3 × moles of C 3 5 × moles of C 5 t = 0 + 3 × moles of C 3 t = 0 3 Results and discussion FAc can be formed via aldol condensation between furfural and acetone. FAc can repeat the above process and then react with another furfural to form a dimer product of F2Ac (Scheme 1 ). 3.1 Catalytic aldol condensation reaction over La2O2CO3-Al2O3 3.1.1 Effect of preparation condition for La2O2CO3-Al2O3 synthesis and performance Firstly, La2O2CO3-Al2O3 catalyst was prepared, and the effect of preparation conditions was investigated(Table 1), including coprecipitation pH, calcination temperature and time. XRD was performed to determine the structure of the prepared samples at different synthesis conditions (Fig. 1 ). For catalysts precipitated at pH of 8 and 9, La2O2CO3 formation was confirmed with the appearance of the characteristic peak at 30.3°, while the peaks were very weak. The peaks indexed to La2O2CO3 intensified at a pH of 10. The comparisons of different precipitation pH (b, f, and g in Fig. 1) indicated that higher pH favored the formation and growth of La2O2CO3. TEM results (Fig. S2) showed the formation of rod-shaped La2O2CO3. As reported in literature [28], the basicity of the synthesis solution played a decisive role in determining the aspect ratio of the La(OH)3 and the final La2O2CO3. The above results confirmed that higher pH favored the formation of La2O2CO3 with long length, such as rod-shaped crystal, which exhibits higher exposure of basic La3+-O2− sites and higher activity in furfural conversion. Comparing the catalysts calcined at difference times (b, d and e in Fig. 1), it can be found the peaks corresponding to La2O2CO3 weakened and the peaks assigned to La2O3 increased with increase of calcination temperature. It indicated that La2O2CO3 was converted to La2O3 with reaction time prolonged. The comparisons of catalysts calcined at different temperatures (a, b and c in Fig. 1) indicated that high temperature calcination can also convert La2O2CO3 into La2O3, but the main phase is still La2O2CO3. We can find that the La2O2CO3-Al2O3 sample showed a rod-shaped structure, which is in good consistent with previous report that higher pH favored the formation of La2O2CO3 with long length, which exhibits higher exposure of basic La3+-O2− sites. The aldol condensation reaction of furfural and acetone was tested. As shown in Table 1, it is found that pH has a significant influence on the catalytic performance of La2O2CO3-Al2O3. For the catalyst prepared at a pH of 8 and calcined at 700 °C for 2 h (No. 1), the initial reaction between furfural and acetone achieved 42.7% furfural conversion. With the pH increasing to 9 and 10, the furfural conversion reached to 45.7% and 92.1%, respectively (No. 2 and 3). Calcination temperature and time also have great effect on the catalytic performance. Furfural conversion declined from 92.1 to 88.9% upon increasing roasting temperature from 700 to 800 °C (No. 4). Furfural conversion also decreased when annealing temperature was lowered to 600 °C (No. 5). The conversion of furfural was found to decrease by increasing the roasting time from 2 to 4 and 6 h (No. 6 and 7). Compared with the sample calcined at 700 °C for 2 h, increasing calcination temperature or prolonging calcination time decreased the activity for furfural conversion. Based on XRD results and reported works [35], it can be proposed that the more active phase of La2O2CO3 decomposed into La2O3. Finally, the sample prepared at a pH of 10, calcination temperature of 700 oC and time of 2 h showed the best performance. The product distribution of all catalysts was also listed in Table 1. It can be found F2Ac selectivity was much higher for catalyst with high conversion, which should be attributed to the gradual transformation of FAc to F2Ac. In Table 2 , five factors and four levels (the molar ratio of furfural/acetone of 1/1, 1/2, 1/3 and 1/4; temperature of 60–90 °C; reaction time of 1–4 h; pressure of 10–40 bar and catalyst dosage of 0.1, 0.15, 0.2 and 0.25 g) orthogonal experiments were designed to optimize furfural conversion and illustrate the effect of reaction conditions. Parameters K and R are average and extreme values, respectively. For all the factors, including molar ratio of furfural/acetone, reaction time, temperature, pressure, and catalyst amount, they took the order of K4 > K3 > K2 > K1. The highest furfural conversion can be obtained by choosing molar ratio of furfural/acetone of 1/4 with 0.25 g catalyst at 90 °C in 4 h and 40 bar. It is noticeable that increasing the acetone amounts can increase furfural conversion. Moreover, parameter R took the order of temperature (R = 19.9) > molar ratio of furfural/acetone (R = 16.2) > reaction time (R = 13.6) > pressure (R = 10.9) > catalyst dosage (R = 9.6). Therefore, reaction temperature, molar ratio of furfural/acetone, and time were selected according to the value of orthogonal experiment R for single factor experimental analysis. 3.1.2 Single-factor experiments optimization of selectivity to FAc and F2Ac La2O2CO3-Al2O3 was studied for the optimization of selectivity to liquid fuel precursors using single-factor experiments. In Fig. 2 , the temperature ranging from 60 to 90 °C was investigated. The catalyst showed a furfural conversion of 77.8% at 60 °C with a FAc selectivity of 35.7% and F2Ac selectivity of 56.4%. With increasing reaction temperature from 60 to 90 °C, the furfural conversion increased to 94.8%. Selectivity of FAc decreased from 35.7 to 27.2% while F2Ac selectivity increased from 56.4 to 71.5%. Fig. 3 showed the profile of effect of furfural/acetone ratio. Furfural conversion was 92.1% at a ratio of 1. Increasing the amount of acetone promotes the conversion of furfural and a conversion of 98.9% could be achieved at a ratio of 1/4. It can also be found that high acetone amount benefits the FAc production, while low acetone amount results in high selectivity of F2Ac. The F2Ac selectivity of 71.5% can be realized at a furfural/acetone ratio of 1/1. In Fig. 4 , the effect of reaction time from 1 to 4 h was studied. After 1 h, the selectivity to F2Ac reaches 33.5% when the furfural conversion rate was 37.7%. When the reaction times increases in 4 h, furfural conversion further increases to 92.1%, and the selectivity to F2Ac was 69.0%. During this period, the selectivity of FAc decreased from 63.8% to 30.5%. This behavior indicates a gradual transformation of FAc into F2Ac, which is reported in many works. In summary, a high furfural conversion can be achieved under mild reaction conditions, indicating the high activity of La2O2CO3-Al2O3 catalyst. The reaction temperature, reactants ratio and reaction time all have impact on the product selectivity. High amount of acetone can enhance the FAc production, while the target synthesis of F2Ac can be realized at high temperature and low acetone amount. The F2Ac yield can reach to 67.8% at 90 °C at a molar ratio of furfural/acetone 1/1, which can be compared with other reports in Table S1. 3.1.3 Catalyst comparison Commercial Al2O3, La2O3 samples and synthesized Al2O3 supported La2O3, La(OH)3, La2O2CO3 (i.e., La2O3-Al2O3, La(OH)3/Al2O3 and La2O2CO3/Al2O3, respectively) were also tested, demonstrating the great advantages of the synthesized La2O2CO3- Al2O3 catalyst (Table 3 ). Al2O3 and La2O3 showed low furfural conversion (< 13.7%) and F2Ac was not detected in the products. However, the combination of Al2O3 and La2O3 (La2O3-Al2O3) exhibited an increased activity, while FAc and F2Ac were achieved with 56.5% and 32.9%, respectively. Significantly, an introduction of La2O2CO3 greatly improved the catalytic activity as both La2O2CO3/Al2O3 and La2O2CO3-Al2O3 catalysts showed good furfural conversion, which could be attributed to the active basic La3+-O2− pairs at the surface. Among the investigated catalysts, La2O2CO3-Al2O3 showed the highest furfural conversion of 92.1%, giving a promising catalyst in basic reactions. 3.1.4 Catalyst stability The stability of La2O2CO3-Al2O3 catalyst was also tested. The used catalysts were washed with ethyl acetate and separated for next cycle. As shown in Fig. 5 , furfural conversion dropped sharply from 99.8 to 57.8% after the first use, indicating the rapid deactivation of the catalyst. The deactivation continued in the 2th and 3th cycles as the furfural conversion decreased to 52.5 and 51.8%. Besides, only a slight change of the selectivity was observed, in which the selectivity of FAc decreased from 66.3 to 64.3% and the selectivity of F2Ac decreased from 30.5 to 29.0%. The total selectivity of adducts decreased and intermediate C8 alcohol (FAc-OH) was detected as the main byproduct (Fig. S3). The formation of FAc-OH indicates the reduction of dehydration ability of the catalyst [36]. As observed in Fig. S4, the color of the catalyst changed from white to yellow after use. It could be suggested that the catalyst surface is covered by insoluble organic compounds, which could cause the deactivation [37]. We preliminarily tried to regenerate the catalyst by calcination to remove the adsorbed species. The results are shown in Table S2. It can be found the activity can be partially improved by regeneration as the furfural conversion increased from 57.8 to 67.3%. We next investigated the deactivation mechanisms of the La2O2CO3-Al2O3 catalyst by performing XRD and TEM. There is not much difference for the XRD patterns of fresh and used La2O2CO3-Al2O3 catalysts (Fig. S5). However, TEM results (Fig. S2) show that the structure of used sample has changed as the boundary became unclear, indicating that the morphology of La2O2CO3 changed after reaction. Based on the above results, we proposed that the catalyst deactivated due to the covering of insoluble products (i.e., F2Ac), and change of morphology, which decreased the number of active basic sites, as confirmed by CO2-TPD (Fig. S6). Thus, the regeneration by calcination is not effective as expected. 3.2 Catalyst characterization 3.2.1 Formation of La2O2CO3-Al2O3 sample The formation of La2O2CO3-Al2O3 sample was discussed by XRD, FT-IR, TGA, N2 adsorption, CO2-TPD and XPS. The phase structure was firstly examined by XRD. Fig. 6 shows the XRD pattern of uncalcined and calcined La2O2CO3-Al2O3 at 700 °C for 2 h. For the sample before calcination, La(OH)3 and La2O(CO3)2•xH2O were observed. For the calcined sample, peaks at 22.34°, 25.17°, 25.78°, 27.60°, 30.35°, 33.67°, 33.88°, 42.51°, 44.40°, 47.44°, 50.23°, 54.74°, 56.88°, and 73.01° were detected, which can be perfectly indexed to a phase of La2O2CO3, confirming the successful synthesis of La2O2CO3. Besides, the La2O3 is also observed with the presence of peaks at 17.2°, 27.2°, 39.3°, and 48.4°. This process can be explained as below. La(OH)3 has the ability to absorb CO2 and H2O and form hydroxycarbonate. When heated to 700 °C in air, bicarbonate is completely converted to La2O2CO3 and La2O3. Thus, La2O2CO3-Al2O3 composed of active La2O2CO3 and La2O3 was formed by coprecipitation method and calcination at 700 °C. The crystal phase structures of La2O2CO3 were also demonstrated by FT-IR analysis (Fig. 7 ).The bands at 1631.3 cm−1 can be attributed to the OH vibration in absorbed water on the uncalcined La2O2CO3, and the bands of between 1300 and 1600 cm−1 revealed the existence of a hydroxycarbonate products [38]. These results indicated that the uncalcined sample had a high capacity for absorbing CO2 and H2O, and can be converted from La(OH)3 into La2O(CO3)2•xH2O by reaction with CO2 [39]. After calcination, the evidence of La2O2CO3 formation was observed, as the bands at 767, 856, 1085, and 1465 cm−1 are interpreted as CO3 2− vibrations associated with La2O2CO3. TGA measurements were made in a flowing air atmosphere to analyze the calcination process for La2O2CO3-Al2O3 formation (Fig. 8 ). Calcination can be divided into three temperature regions. The first was from room temperature range to about 250 °C, the second was in the range of 250–450 °C, the third was at 450–800 °C. The stepwise weight loss of the uncalcined La2O2CO3-Al2O3 precursor also indicated the formation of lanthanum carbonate, which is in consistent with the XRD and IR results. It is speculated that the first effect is due to the release of the adsorbed water on the surface of uncalcined La2O2CO3-Al2O3 and the forming lanthanum carbonate La2O(CO3)2•xH2O. This process corresponds to a total weight loss of approximately 4%. In the range of 250–450 °C, it releases the remaining water and lanthanum oxide carbonate began to decompose into La2O2CO3, equivalent to a weight loss of about 16.8% weight. In the range of 450–800 °C, La2O2CO3-Al2O3 is finally obtained and would decompose into La2O3 at high temperature and long calcination time. It can be found that the La2O2CO3-Al2O3 calcined at 700 °C contains La2O2CO3 and La2O3, which is in consistent with XRD results. For the calcined La2O2CO3-Al2O3 catalyst, a weight loss about 3.8% was observed before 300 °C, indicating the good stability of the catalyst. The loss continued above 700 °C, which could be the transformation of La2O2CO3 to stable La2O3. Based on these results, the reduced activity for La2O2CO3-Al2O3 catalyst calcined at 800 °C (Table 1) could be due to the decomposition of active La2O2CO3 phase, in compared with that calcined at 700 °C. The insufficient calcination (e.g., 600 °C) would contain La2O(CO3)2•xH2O, which is also not good for the activity. N2 adsorption was performed to obtain the specific surface area, pore volume and pore size of samples (Table 4 ). Laser diffraction particle size analyzer was used to measure the diameter of particles (Fig. S7). The specific surface area of uncalcined La2O2CO3-Al2O3 was 7.77 m2/g, the pore volume of 2.95 × 10−2 cm3/g, the average pore diameter was 3.06 nm, and particle diameter 2.75 μm. The specific surface area of La2O2CO3-Al2O3 was increased to 17.18 m2/g, and the pore volume to 4.15 × 10−2 cm3/g, the average pore diameter was 3.81 nm, and the particle diameter 2.72 μm. The increase of surface area and pore volume could be attributed to the release of CO2 during calcination, which corresponds to the transformation of La2O(CO3)2•xH2O to La2O2CO3. 3.2.2 Properties of La2O2CO3-Al2O3 sample CO2-TPD spectra of all samples are shown in Fig. 9 . Generally, the oxides contain surface sites of weak (OH− groups), medium (M2+-O2− pairs), and strong (O2− anions) basicity. It is reported that carbonation of La2O3 under CO2 flow happens about 500 °C while the decomposition of La2O2CO3 occurs above 700 °C [40,41]. Thus, the catalysts will not release CO2 in our investigated temperature range. The TPD signals reveal the desorption of pre-adsorbed CO2 of catalysts. Al2O3 mainly shows weak basic sites, arising from the surface OH groups. The combination of La2O3 and Al2O3 (La2O3-Al2O3) increased the amounts of medium-strength basic sites, which are mainly from the La3+-O2− pairs. It can be proposed that the medium-strength basic sites are active for the aldol condensation reactions as La2O3-Al2O3 catalyst showed higher furfural conversion than Al2O3. For La(OH)3/Al2O3 catalyst, large amounts of strong-strength basic sites were observed. However, La(OH)3/Al2O3 showed low furfural conversion. Noticeably, La2O2CO3-Al2O3 and La2O2CO3/Al2O3 exhibited greatly enhanced medium-strength basic sites due to the introduction of La2O2CO3 component, which showed high activity in the investigated catalysts. The above results further demonstrate that medium-strength La3+-O2− sites are highly active for aldol condensation reactions. XPS is performed to characterize chemical binding and elements states (Fig. 10 ). The La 3d5/2 split can be used for characterization of La compounds [42]. In the literature, the cleavage of La(OH)3 and La2O3 was 3.6 eV and 4.6 eV, respectively. The La 3d5/2 main peaks of the uncalcined La2O2CO3-Al2O3 sample are found at 835.6 and 838.9 eV, with a peak splitting of 3.3 eV, which is close to the literature value of La(OH)3 compound. The peaks of La 3d5/2 of La2O2CO3-Al2O3 are at approximately 834.5 and 838.1 eV. The split is much lower than that of La2O3. Combined with XRD results, it can be concluded that the surface of La2O2CO3-Al2O3 is mainly La2O2CO3 species, which plays key role for the enhancement of activity. In Fig. 10b, the C 1 s spectra shows two carbon species. The lower energy peak is considered carbon indeterminate and a value of 284.13 eV was specified as reference. The C 1 s peak at 288.58 eV can be assigned to carbonate species. The presence of carbonate C 1 s peak on the uncalcined sample indicated that lanthanum carbonate is formed by adsorbing CO2, which is consistent with the previous XRD, IR, and TG analysis. It can be found the surface of the as-prepared sample is both strongly hydroxylated and carbonated. The state of O 1 s indicated that two distinct oxygen species for O 1 s can be well distinguished. The 530.0 eV primary peak in the O 1 s spectrum corresponds to oxygen ions in the crystal lattice, while the spectral line at 531.2 eV can be ascribed to the absorbed oxygen, such as conventional carbonate or hydroxyl assignments. It can be found that most of the carbonate and hydroxyl groups are removed from the surface after calcination. 4 Conclusions La2O2CO3-Al2O3 synthesized by coprecipitation method showed good performance in aldol condensation reaction of furfural and acetone to produce liquid fuel intermediates. The synthesis conditions were studied, including coprecipitation pH, calcination temperature and time. It was found that rod-shaped La2O2CO3 was formed at higher coprecipitation pH, which exhibits higher exposure of basic La3+-O2− sites and shows good performance in aldol condensation reactions. With the increase of calcination temperature and time, La2O2CO3 gradually transformed into La2O3 while the activity for aldol condensation decreased. This work found that La2O2CO3 is more effective than La2O3 component, and the morphology of La2O2CO3 has a great effect on the catalytic performance in aldol condensation reactions. These findings may give some suggestions for a further design of highly dispersed La catalysts. Significantly, a F2Ac yield of 67.8% can be obtained at a furfural/acetone molar ratio of 1/1 and a reaction temperature of 90 °C, which is superior to many reported works. coredata.dc:description: Jet fuel precursors (4-(2-furyl)-3-buten-2-one (FAc) and 1,5-di-2-furanyl-1,4-pentadien-3-one (F2Ac)) can be produced from aldol condensation between furfural and acetone over basic catalysts. However, there is still a need to develop efficient alkaline catalysts and understand the role of alkaline sites. In this work, La2O2CO3-Al2O3 catalyst was successfully prepared by coprecipitation and the effect of preparation conditions on the properties and catalytic performance was investigated. Experiments showed that La2O2CO3 and La2O3 were formed after calcination, and the activity was greatly improved by the introduction of La2O2CO3. At higher coprecipitation pH, rod-shaped La2O2CO3 was formed, which exhibits higher exposure of basic La3+-O2− sites and shows good performance in aldol condensation reactions. The catalytic performance of La2O2CO3-Al2O3 in aldol condensation of furfural with acetone was also evaluated and compared with that of Al2O3, La2O3, La2O3-Al2O3, La(OH)₃/Al2O3 and La2O2CO3/Al2O3. A total conversion of furfural can be realized with F2Ac yield of 67.8% at a furfural/acetone ratio of 1/1 and 90 °C, with a FAc yield of 25.8% at the same time. The deactivation mechanism of the La2O2CO3-Al2O3 catalyst was also studied.
coredata.dc:title: Synthesis of jet fuel intermediates via aldol condensation of biomass-derived furfural with lanthanide catalyst
